Lighting Model¶

Reusable LightingModel Component¶

The LightingModel component is an OpenMDAO component, which could be used by multiple exhibits to help determine their individual lighting configuration. The LightingModel uses a Lights class to configure both a nominal and new design lighting configuration, then perform calculations based on the configurations.

LightingModel Class Input Attributes¶

    numBulbs = Float(1.0, iotype='in', desc='number of bulbs to replace')

LightingModel Class Output Attributes¶

    yearlykWhNominal = Float(1.0, iotype='out', desc='yearly power output (kWh)')
    recurringCostsNominal = Array(np.array([[0.0,0.0,6000,0.0,0.0,6000,0.0,0.0,6000,0.0]]), dtype=numpy_float,
                                  shape=(1,10), iotype='out')

    yearlykWh = Float(1.0, iotype='out', desc='yearly power output (kWh)')
    recurringCosts = Array(np.array([[0.0,0.0,6000,0.0,0.0,6000,0.0,0.0,6000,0.0]]), dtype=numpy_float,
                           shape=(1,10), iotype='out')

LightingModel Class Constants¶

    years = 10   #: Years to project out recurring costs

LightingModel Class Definition¶

class Common.Lighting.Lighting.LightingModel(lightObjNew, lightObjOld)[source]¶

The LightingModel is a wrapper for a power and cost calculation in regard to replacing current lighting fixtures with more energy

__init__(lightObjNew, lightObjOld)[source]¶

Overrides the initialization of the OpenMDAO Component class. The purpose is to provide a way to customize and reuse this class for many different exhibits.

Parameters:
  • lightObjNew – Configured Lights class for new bulbs
  • lightObjOld – Configured Lights class for old bulbs
Returns:

Initialized LightingModel object
execute()[source]¶

The method for an OpenMDAO component that is required to be filled out with the internal behavior, and is called each time OpenMDAO has changed the input values. After execution, the new output values are then read from the component. This component executes to functions; one to calculate power, and one to calculate the initial capital cost associated with the configuration of the input values.

Returns:None

Lights Class¶

class Common.Lighting.calc_lighting.Lights(numBulbs, scaleRatio, bulbWatts, bulbCost, bulbLife, hoursOnPerDay, current)[source]¶
__init__(numBulbs, scaleRatio, bulbWatts, bulbCost, bulbLife, hoursOnPerDay, current)[source]¶

Lights is a reuseable and general class for describing the lights configuration for any Georgia Aquarium exhibit. The class can be used as part of the higher level exhibit class to come up with a total power use and total investment and recurring costs for the exhibit.

Parameters:
  • numBulbs – Number of light bulbs/fixtures for this configuration
  • scaleRatio – The number of new bulbs needed to replace one old one
  • bulbWatts – The rating of the bulbs for this configuration
  • bulbCost – The cost in dollars of a single bulb
  • bulbLife – The lifespan in hours for the configured bulb
  • hoursOnPerDay –
  • current –
Returns:
initial_cost[source]¶

Calculates the first year cost of the lighting configuration. This takes into account if the lighting configuration is the nominal one, and returns a cost of zero, making the assumption that we already have lights at the current moment in time and do not need to immediately replace them.

Returns:The cost for the current configuration for the initial year of analysis.
power_per_year[source]¶

Calculates the total amount of power in kWh for the current lighting configuration

Returns:Total amount of power in kWh used by the lights
print_config()[source]¶

Prints the configuration to console.

Returns:None
recurrance_period[source]¶

Calculates the number of years required before replacing a bulb

Returns:pandas.Series of length equal to the number of configurations defined, where each value represents the length in years until the associated lights will need to be replaced
recurring_cost[source]¶

Calculates the cost required at the recurrance_period.

Note

Assumes all lights go out at once.

Returns:pandas.Series of length equal to the number of configurations defined, where each value is the cost in dollars each time you have to replace the lights.
yearly_cost(maxYears)[source]¶

Yearly cost of the lighting configuration over the length of maxYears.

Parameters:maxYears – The number of years out to calculate the recurring cost
Returns:numpy.ndarray with length of maxYears
